p: The mechanism of ranpirnase antiviral activity is hypothesized as being an RNA interference pathway which can result in direct virus inhibition and alterations in the host cell gene expression [ 19]. The mechanism of selective cytotoxicity in transformed cells is well studied, where endocytosis [ 20] is followed by the degradation of dsRNA, such as tRNA, which results in halting protein synthesis and arrest of the cell cycle [ 21]. Proposed mechanisms of antiviral activity include degradation of viral RNA [ 16] and disruption of TNF-Î± signaling [ 22]. Ranpirnase is a highly stable water-soluble molecule but has never been recorded to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB).
